results.title: The Dissenter
results.creator_credit: Bill Jersey and Barr Media Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Renaissance”.
This program documents the lives and ideas of dissenters who suffered death and/or excommunication in their challenge to the power of the Church. Through dramatic re-enactments you meet Jan Hus, John Wyclif, Martin Luther, Argula Von Grumbach, and others who questioned established authority. The essence of dissent is captured through interviews with modern day dissenters fighting orthodoxy.

results.title: The Dispersal of seeds and fruits
results.brief_description: Considers the origin of seeds and fruits and discusses the need to spread these structures in order to avoid excessive competition, and to spread the species. Illustrates the agencies for dispersal - wind, animal and less common, water.

results.title: The Disorderly orderly
results.creator_credit: Frank Tashlin, Paul Jones and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: In his eighth, and final, collaboration with director Frank Tashlin, Jerry Lewis plays Jerome Littlefield, a nurse in a sanatorium whose manic and clumsy antics manage to upset patients and staff alike. Lewis is given free reign here to display his usual brand of silly, goofy and slapstick physical humour. Typically, although Jerome is a sympathetic attendant, he effortlessly manages to derail those he cares for. In one hilarious scene a hypochondriac patient relays her many maladies as Lewis displays her symptoms. Another highlight is a quite mad chase through hilly streets, with an ambulance in pursuit of a freewheeling stretcher (with a stunned patient aboard), ending in a catastrophic encounter with numerous supermarket trolleys. As this comedy is set in a hospital, some salient points are made about systemic corruption and profit margins that increase with a simultaneous decline in care. But quite expectedly, the darker tones of the film are marginalised in favour of comedic set-pieces, consistent with Lewis’ other work, and highlights his talent for physical idiocy and facial expressiveness. Also stars Glenda Farrell, Everett Sloane, Karen Sharpe and Kathleen Freeman.

results.title: The Disney channel. -Volume 5.
results.brief_description: Features 2 hours of entertainment from the Disney channel. Included in this volume: GOOD MORNING MICKEY: “Symphony hour; WELCOME TO POOH CORNER: “Eeyore’s costume party”; directed by Philip F. Messina, based on the books by A. A. Milne and illustrated by Ernest H. Shepard. Narrated by Laurie Mann: MOUSE FACTORY: “Home owners”; produced and directed by Ward Kimball and featuring Jim Backus as Mickey’s friend: DONALD DUCK PRESENTS: “Magic and music” plus “Peter and the wolf”; directed by Clyde Geronimi and told by Stirling Holloway: MOUSERCISE; produced by George Taweel, directed by Gordon Myers and featuring Kellyn, Donald, Goofy and friends. There are tracking problems at the beginning of this segment.

results.title: The Disney channel. - Volume 2
results.brief_description: Memorable moments from the Disney channel are included on this tape including: GOOD MORNING MICKEY “Lion’s down”; Goofy features in this cartoon directed by Jack Kinney; WELCOME TO POOH CORNER “Spaghetti”; Tigger and Winnie the Pooh tackle some spaghetti, produced by Caroline Hay and directed by Donald R. Ham; THE MOUSE FACTORY “The Reluctant dragon”; Not all dragons breathe fire and wreak fear amongst men as this story shows, produced and directed by Ward Kimball; DONALD DUCK PRESENTS “A Day at Disneyland”; You’ll feel like you’ve been there after this expedition, produced by Matt Oppenheimer and directed by Barry Elliott; MOUSERCISE; Join Kellyn, Mickey and friends for some healthy exercise. Produced by George Taweel and directed by Gordon Myers.

results.title: The Dismissal
results.creator_credit: John Power, Carl Schultz, George Ogilvie, Phil Noyce, George Miller, Terry Hayes and Kennedy-Miller
results.brief_description: A fictional account of the events that led up to the decision, made by Sir John Kerr, to sack Gough Whitlam as Prime Minister and appoint Malcolm Fraser in his place.

constellations_other.name: George Miller
constellations_other.description: For a guy who started his career as a physician, George Miller sure is a diverse filmmaker.

results.creator_credit_for_label: John Power, Carl Schultz, George Ogilvie, Phil Noyce, George Miller, Terry Hayes and Kennedy-Miller
results.description: A fictional account of the events that led up to the decision, made by Sir John Kerr, to sack Gough Whitlam as Prime Minister and appoint Malcolm Fraser in his place. The events covered occurred over the period between 1972 and 1975 and have been arranged, in the film, into six parts. Cast: Peter Carroll, Bill Hunter, John Hargreaves, John Meillon, Max Phipps, John Stanton, Arthur Dignam, Ruth Cracknell, Nancy Hayes.

results.title: The Dish [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Rob Sitch, Jane Kennedy, Tom Gleisner, Santo Cilauro, Robert Hirsch and Working Dog
results.brief_description: Based on a true story, ‘The Dish’ tells the story of the first landing on the moon and the role a bunch of technicians in remote Australia played in delivering those images to the world. In stark contrast to images we’ve seen before in films and the news of NASA control rooms - hundreds of experts working around the clock to ensure a successful mission - the film segues to the activities of staff in the sleepy remote town of Parkes, South Australia, where the equal task of tracking the lunar module was shared with NASA. After we witness the Australian’s low-key approach to this responsibility what is revealed in this gentle comedy is a cultural critique; a celebration of the unique qualities that make us Australian and defines our cultural values.

results.title: The Discreet charm of the bourgeoisie
results.creator_credit: Luis Bunuel, Serge Silberman and Greenwich Film Production Paris
results.brief_description: The efforts of a group of friends to dine together are continually frustrated in this often hilarious surrealistic fable. As if in a dream, things go awry for all the characters in this, Luis Bunuel’s deliciously comical and brilliantly performed masterpiece. Co-written by Bunuel and Jean-Claude Carriere. English subtitles.

results.title: The Discovery of television
results.creator_credit: John Lloyd, Alasdair Milne, BBC-TV and JBM Productions
results.brief_description: The discovery and development of television is not the story of the efforts of a single person, but of many people. It is a search through a tangled web of scientific discoveries, inventions, and developments, of ideas tried and rejected and tried again, culminating with the efforts of an enthusiastic team of professionals led by Sir Isaac Shoenberg. Describes the early experiments in television leading to the first regular broadcasts from London beginning on 2nd November 1936. The work of the pioneers is reconstructed using contemporary records and interviews.
